article.name: Sophos Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.title: Sophos Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.body:
In this article, you will learn how to integrate Sophos endpoint security with SecurityCoach. Once you set up this integration, data provided by Sophos will be available under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Tip:SecurityCoach also supports integrating Sophos as a Splunk vendor. If your organization uses Splunk for security information and event management, we recommend integrating through Splunk instead by following our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.

To set up the Sophos integration with SecurityCoach you’ll need Sophos API credentials from your Sophos console and then enter the credentials in your KSAT console.

Set Up the Integration in Your Sophos Console

  1. Log in to your Sophos console.
  2. Navigate to Global Settings > API Credentials Management.

  3. Click Add Credential.

  4. In the Add credential pop-up window, enter a Credential name for your integration, such as “KnowBe4 Integration”.
  5. Enter a Description for your integration, such as “KnowBe4 Sophos Integration”.

  6. In the Role drop-down menu, select Service Principal ReadOnly.

  7. Click Add.
  8. On the API credential summary page, copy and save your Client ID and Client Secret in a place you can easily access. You’ll need these credentials to complete the integration.

Important:The Client Secret will only be shown once. When you’re ready to copy your Client Secret, click Show Client Secret.

Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console

Once you have copied your API credentials from your Sophos account, you can set up the integration in your KSAT console. To integrate Sophos in your KSAT console, follow the steps below.

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate the Sophos card and click Configure.
  3. Enter the Client ID and Client Secret that you saved in your Set Up the Integration in Your Sophos Console section of this article.

  4. Click Connect.

Map Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Sophos, you can map your users either through mapping rules (recommended) or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Sophos on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.

images.alt:
This image displays the Sophos Central management console, specifically the **Global Settings** page, accessible via the URL `cloud.sophos.com/manage/overview/settings-list`.

**UI Structure and Context:**

*   **Navigation Pane (Left):** A dark gray vertical navigation bar lists core platform areas. The item **Global Settings** (represented by a gear icon) is currently selected and highlighted in blue, indicating the active page. This pane also lists product categories under "MY PRODUCTS."
*   **Main Content Area (Right):** The primary title is **Global Settings**, with the subtitle "Manage your settings."

**Key Content and Text:**

The main area is divided into sections, starting with **Administration** (indicated by a gear icon). This section lists administrative configuration options as blue hyperlinks, each followed by a description:

*   Directory service: Manage your directory services to synchronize users, devices, and groups with Sophos Central.
*   Role Management: Manage Administration Roles.
*   API Token Management: Manage API tokens used for secure access to Sophos Central APIs.
*   **API Credentials Management (Highlighted):** This link is visually emphasized with an orange border. The accompanying text states: "Create and manage API credentials and Service Principal roles."
*   Sophos sign-in settings: Manage sign-in settings for all Sophos Central accounts and applications.
*   Verify domains: Verify domains used by Sophos products and Central federated sign-on.
*   Federated identity providers: Manage identity providers for federated sign-in.
*   Software packages: View available endpoint and server protection software packages and manage labels and comments.

A subsequent section heading, **General** (also with a gear icon), is partially visible at the bottom.

This image displays the **API Credentials Management** screen within the **Sophos Central** administrative interface.

**UI Context and Navigation:**

*   **Platform:** Sophos Central (Branding on the left navigation panel).
*   **Location:** The main page title is **API Credentials Management**. The breadcrumb path is displayed as *Settings / API Credentials Management*.
*   **Tabs:** Two tabs are present below the title: **Credentials** (active, highlighted in blue) and **Roles** (inactive).
*   **User Status:** The logged-in user is identified via a top-right dropdown as **Administrator**, with the assigned role designated as **SA · Super Admin**.

**Key Information and Actions:**

*   **Limit Note:** A restriction is indicated by the text: "Note: You may create up to 10 credentials."
*   **Primary Action:** A prominent blue button, labeled **Add Credential**, is located on the right side of the content area. (An overlaid orange arrow points specifically to this button, indicating an intended user action.)
*   **Data View:** The view immediately transitions to a data table, partially visible, listing column headers such as NAME, CREDENTIAL ID, CREATED ON, and LAST USED ON.

The image displays a modal dialog titled **"Add credential"**. This dialog requires user input across three primary fields:

1.  **Credential name\*** (Required text input)
2.  **Description** (Optional text input)
3.  **Role\*** (Required dropdown selection, accompanied by a **Details** hyperlink)

A **Notes** section provides two key informational points:
*   "Upon clicking the Add button, a Client ID and Client Secret will be generated."
*   "Credentials will expire in 36 months."

The dialog is controlled by two action buttons located in the footer: **Cancel** (secondary action) and **Add** (primary, highlighted action). A standard close icon (X) is present in the upper right corner.

This image displays a modal window titled **"Add credential"** used for configuring a new service principal.

**UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **Header:** The modal title is "Add credential". A standard 'X' icon is visible in the top right corner for closing the window.
2.  **Input Fields:**
    *   **"Credential name\*"**: A required text input field (indicated by the asterisk) for naming the new credential.
    *   **"Description"**: An optional text input field.
3.  **Role Selection (Dropdown/List):** A dark gray context menu is open, displaying a list of selectable service principal roles.
    *   **Selected Role:** **"Service Principal ReadOnly"** is highlighted in orange and contains a checkmark ($\checkmark$), indicating it is the current selection.
    *   **Other Visible Roles (Top to Bottom):**
        *   Service Principal Super Admin
        *   $\checkmark$ Service Principal ReadOnly (Selected)
        *   Service Principal Management
        *   Service Principal Forensics
        *   Service Principal Directory Sync
        *   Service Principal Firewall
4.  **Informational Text:** Partially visible text below the selection area states that "Client ID and Client Secret will be generated."
5.  **Action Buttons (Footer):**
    *   **Cancel** (Text link/button)
    *   **Add** (Primary blue button)

The image displays the **API credential summary** screen, detailing an existing API key configuration.

**Key UI Elements and Data Fields:**

*   **Header and Actions:** The page is titled "API credential summary." A "Delete" button is visible in the upper right corner.
*   **Metadata:** Essential fields and their corresponding values are listed:
    *   **Name:** KB4 Integration
    *   **Created on:** Oct 09, 2023
    *   **Expires on:** Oct 08, 2026
    *   **Description:** KB4 Sophos Integration
*   **Client ID:** The field displays a partially obscured (blurred) alphanumeric value, followed by a light blue **Copy** button for quick transfer.
*   **Client Secret:** The secret is initially masked, displaying a blue hyperlink labeled **Show Client Secret**.
*   **Security Warning:** A critical warning is noted immediately below the Client Secret field: "Note: For security reasons, the Client Secret will only be shown one time. Click the Show Client Secret link only when you are ready to implement it."
*   **Role:** The access permission is listed as **Service Principal ReadOnly**, displayed as a blue hyperlink.

This screen displays the interface for configuring a Sophos vendor integration.

**Header and Guidance:**
*   **Page Title:** `Sophos`
*   **Navigation:** A link labeled `← Back to Integrations` is located in the top right corner.
*   **Instructional Text:** Provides a link for documentation: `For more information about configuring this vendor integration, see our Sophos Integration Guide for SecurityCoach. ↗` (The link includes an external icon).

**Integration Input Panel:**
The configuration is presented within a distinct white panel requiring two authentication credentials:
1.  **Client ID:** An empty text field for inputting the Client ID.
2.  **Client Secret:** An empty text field for inputting the Client Secret.

**Actions:**
Below the input fields, the following controls are available:
*   **Connect:** Primary button (blue outline) used to initiate the connection attempt with the vendor using the provided credentials.
*   **Cancel:** Secondary link used to abort the configuration process.

The image displays the **Sophos User Mapping** configuration interface, designed for linking Sophos endpoint identifiers to KMSAT user records.

**Header and Context:**
The page title is "Sophos User Mapping." Descriptive text instructs users to configure mapping rules or upload a CSV file. A hyperlink references the "Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article."

**Navigation:**
The interface uses tabbed navigation:
1.  **Mapping Rules (Recommended)** (Active tab)
2.  **CSV File Upload** (Inactive tab)

**Active Configuration Area (Mapping Rules):**
The active section is titled "**Configure Mapping Rules**" and is described as the recommended method. The core element is a single, editable mapping rule:

*   **Sophos** field: A pre-defined label/selection reading "Hostname."
*   **Operator:** The literal text "is."
*   **Knowbe4 User Data Field:** A dropdown selection box with the placeholder text "Select option."
*   An action button labeled "Add Field" is associated with the mapping row.
*   A link below the rule allows users to "Add Another Rule."

**Action Buttons:**
At the bottom of the interface, two persistent action buttons are present:
1.  **Save** (Primary, blue button)
2.  **Delete Integration** (Secondary, bordered button)
